LONDON Donald Trump told Britons on Sunday he supported Brexit

column3: Trump
column4: the presumptive Republican U.S. presidential candidate
column5: said in a newspaper interview he was backing an ""out"" vote. ""I would personally be more inclined to leave
column6: for a lot of reasons like having a lot less bureaucracy
column7: he told the Sunday Times. ""But I am not a British citizen. This is just my opinion.""The billionaire businessman also told the newspaper that he would seek to have good relationships internationally if he were elected president in November
column8: including with David Cameron. The British Prime Minister has in the past called Trump's proposed temporary ban on Muslims entering the United States ""divisive

column1: Trump said in May that Britain would be better off outside the EU because of high levels of migration.The latest opinion polls showed the 'Remain' camp recovering some momentum
column2: although the overall picture remains one of an evenly split electorate.

column1: Trump
column2: whose mother was Scottish

column1: 1	1	http://reuters.com/article/us-florida-shooting-guns-idUSKCN0Z40AA	Democrats' new line on gun control: Do it for national security	"
By Richard Cowan and Doina Chiacu
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Democrats pushing for gun curbs after the latest mass shooting in the United States are co-opting a Republican mantra to build public support and defang opposition: it's time to get tough on national security.Shoring up national security has long been a pillar of Republican orthodoxy
column2: as has staunch opposition to gun control.But the massacre of 49 people in Orlando
column3: Florida
column4: last Sunday
column5: the deadliest mass shooting in modern U.S. history
column6: by a gunman who pledged loyalty to Islamist militants may be leaving Republicans on shakier ground.With national security driving the debate
column7: Democrats see a more powerful argument than simply advocating the need to curb gun violence in a country of 320 million that has more than 310 million weapons.Although the Orlando gunman
column8: Omar Mateen
column9: is believed to have had no help from extremist Islamist groups in targeting a gay nightclub
column10: he had been investigated by U.S. authorities for possible links to terrorism and subsequently cleared.That prompted Democrats to clamor for legislation to expand background checks and prevent people on U.S. terrorism watch lists from buying guns. Votes on four measures were scheduled Monday in the U.S. Senate
column11: two sponsored by Democrats and two by Republicans. Many Republicans
column13: oppose strict gun curbs partly on constitutional grounds.""Every senator is now going to have to say
column14: whether they're for terrorists getting guns or against terrorists getting guns
column15: Democrat Senator Chuck Schumer told reporters on Thursday.""The terrorists that we need to fear are not on the streets of Aleppo
column16: or Mosul or Fallujah. They're on the streets of the United States and they will have guns unless we pass tough laws
column19: Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton and Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson all took the tack this week that gun measures were a safeguard against terrorism.

column1: Republicans have long criticized Obama for not being tough enough on national security and doing more in the fight against Islamic State.The Orlando massacre and the San Bernardino
column2: California shooting in December by a couple inspired by Islamic State  captured the attention of the American public in a way previous mass shootings have not
column3: said Tom Diaz
column4: a former member of the National Rifle Association gun rights lobby who now backs gun control.""They've changed the dynamic of this whole issue
column5: said Diaz
column6: an author and expert on terrorism and the gun industry.That shift in sentiment has heartened the families of the 20 elementary school children and six staff members killed in Newtown
column7: Connecticut in 2012
column8: who championed the last big
column10: on gun control.About 71 percent of Americans
column11: including eight out of 10 Democrats and nearly six out of 10 Republicans
column12: favor at least moderate regulations and restrictions on guns
column13: according to a Reuters/Ipsos poll conducted from Monday to Thursday. That was up from 60 percent in late 2013 and late 2014.

column1: REPUBLICANS AND CONSTITUTIONAL RIGHTS
Diaz believes Republicans must look as if they care about keeping guns out of the hands of so-called homegrown extremists
column2: while balancing issues of due process and the Constitution's Second Amendment right to bear arms that form the backbone of the NRA's opposition to gun control.Republicans say new laws won't necessarily keep weapons out of the hands of people intent on doing harm
column3: and are keen to avoid twinning the two issues. ""This is not a gun control issue
column4: U.S. Senator Ted Cruz  said on Thursday. ""This is a terrorism issue.""

column1: Republican strategist Ron Bonjean said Democrats ""must be careful about overplaying their hand with rhetoric that could sound like government overreach to Americans who believe in the Second Amendment.""Even if the current efforts fail
column2: the new push on national security may prove Democrats' best shot at eventually luring Republican support on an issue that has floundered for decades.""This is a chance for the Democrats to talk in tough terms about safety and security and also to link that to the gun issue
column3: said Robert Spitzer
column4: political science professor at State University of New York at Cortland.Some notable Republicans appeared willing this week to engage in the debate on gun control. The party's presumptive presidential nominee
column5: Donald Trump
column6: vowed to meet with the NRA to talk about ways to bar people on certain government watch lists from buying guns.The top Republican in the Senate
column7: Majority Leader Mitch McConnell
column8: said he was open to suggestions from experts on how to prevent terrorism suspects from acquiring firearms and called the Orlando shooting a ""calculated act of terror.""But it was unclear whether Trump or McConnell would throw their weight behind any measures acceptable to Democrats.Democratic U.S. Representative Jim Himes said he did not hold out great hope that the gun legislation would advance.""The reason you won't see a compromise anytime soon is because Congress actually acting in the wake of Orlando would be a tacit admission on the other side that guns had something to do with what happened in Orlando as opposed to ISIS
column10: using an acronym for Islamic State. (Editing by Mary Milliken)"	['Clinton'

column1: 2	2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-idUSKCN0Z32BX	Clinton's lead over Trump slips after Florida shooting: Reuters/Ipsos poll	"
By Chris Kahn
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Donald Trump chipped away at Hillary Clinton's lead in the presidential race this week
column2: according to a Reuters/Ipsos poll released on Friday
column3: as the candidates clashed over how to respond to the worst mass shooting in modern U.S. history.The poll
column4: conducted from Monday to Friday
column5: showed Clinton
column6: the presumptive Democratic nominee
column7: with a 10.7 point lead among likely voters over Trump
column8: her likely Republican rival in the November presidential election. That's down from a lead of 14.3 points for Clinton on Sunday
column9: the day an American-born shooter who declared allegiance to militant group Islamic State killed 49 people at a gay nightclub in Orlando
column10: Florida.Trump seized on the attack to sharpen his security proposals
column11: saying he would block immigration to the United States from any country with a ""proven history of terrorism"" against America and its allies if elected. The pledge fine-tuned an earlier vow
column12: made after the attacks last year in Paris and California
column13: to ban the entry of all Muslims into the United States.He also called for measures to make it more difficult for suspected terrorists to obtain firearms
column14: veering from the Republican Party's general opposition to gun control.

column1: While Trump's comments on both Muslims and guns dismayed some Republican elites
column2: they may have cheered some voters.Some 45 percent of Americans said they supported Trump's idea to suspend Muslim immigration
column3: up from 41.9 percent at the start of the month
column4: according to the poll. Meanwhile
column5: about 70 percent of Americans
column6: including a majority of Democrats and Republicans
column7: said they wanted to see at least moderate regulations and restrictions on guns
column8: up from 60 percent in similar polls in 2013 and 2014.

column1: Clinton focused her response to the Orlando attack on the need to boost intelligence gathering and defeat Islamic State and what she called ""radical jihadist terrorism
column2: while warning against demonizing Muslim-Americans. She also repeated her calls for tougher gun control measures
column3: including a ban on assault weapons.As usual after a major attack
column4: ""terrorism"" jumped to the top concern among all adults in the poll - rising above the economy
column5: health care and other major issues.

column1: The poll's five-day average showed that 45.5 percent of likely American voters supported Clinton
column2: while 34.8 percent supported Trump
column3: and another 19.7 percent did not support either candidate. On Sunday
column4: Clinton's support was at 46.6 percent
column5: versus Trump's 32.3 percent.The Reuters/Ipsos poll was conducted online in English with adults living in the continental United States
column6: Alaska and Hawaii. The political horserace poll included 1
column7: 133 likely voters and has a credibility interval
column8: a measure of the poll's accuracy
column9: of 3.4 percentage points. (Editing by Richard Valdmanis and Leslie Adler)"	['Clinton'

column1: 3	3	http://reuters.com/article/us-new-york-fantasysports-idUSKCN0Z40AM	New York lawmakers vote to legalize fantasy sports games	"
By James Odato
| ALBANY
column2: N.Y.

column1: ALBANY
column2: N.Y. Fantasy sports moved a step closer to being legal in New York on Saturday when lawmakers approved the daily and season-long games
column3: clearing a path for FanDuel
column4: DraftKings and others to offer them to millions of players in the state.The multibillion-dollar industry
column5: where players draft fantasy teams for sports including football
column6: basketball and baseball
column7: has drawn increased scrutiny since last year with the attorneys general of several U.S. states
column8: including New York
column10: questioning the legality of the games.New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman had held off on pursuing litigation against the fantasy companies for what he claimed were illegal gambling operations
column11: and the companies have suspended their ""games of skill"" while the proposed legislation was in train.New York's Senate passed the measure 45-17 early Saturday morning
column12: sending the legislation that regulates and taxes the operators of fantasy sports games to Governor Andrew Cuomo.It is unclear whether Cuomo will sign the legislation
column13: which the Assembly passed on Friday. Daily fantasy sports
column14: a turbocharged version of the season-long game where players draft teams in live games played in just one evening or over a weekend
column15: has boomed over the past decade.State Assembly Gaming Committee Chairman J. Gary Pretlow predicted Cuomo would endorse the bill
column16: partly because many young New York voters play the fantasy games and because it would generate tax revenues.

column1: It's a good thing for New Yorkers because there are more than three and half million participants
column2: most of them millennials
column3: Pretlow said.DraftKings
column4: which has dominated the industry along with FanDuel
column5: praised the legislation as providing what it called a ""sensible framework for regulating our games"". In a statement on Saturday
column6: the company said it would resume operations soon with new rules that provide ""fairness and transparency at the core"" of all its contests
column7: assuming the governor signs the legislation.FanDuel pointed out that New York was the seventh state to pass a fantasy sports bill this year
column8: following Colorado

column1: It speaks to the popularity of our game"" said Nigel Eccles
column2: the company's CEO and co-founder.The New York legislation calls for a 15 percent annual state tax on gross revenues of all sports fantasy contests with an entry fee. Another 0.5 percent will be assessed each year on the companies with a maximum of $50
column3: 000.State Senator John Bonacic
column4: who sponsored the bill
column5: estimates annual state revenues will be about $5.5 million
column6: adding that the measure is ""going to make a lot of New Yorkers very happy"".

column1: The legislation survived heavy opposition from casino companies operating in New York.Opponents said it would weaken New York's current gaming operations
column2: including the horse racing industry which has been propped up by state government
column3: by giving gamblers more options.After intense lobbying from the fantasy gaming industry
column4: which retained former pro quarterbacks Jim Kelly and Vinny Testaverde to promote the games
column5: lawmakers beat a June 30 deadline to set regulations.Schneiderman said in a statement on Saturday that he would enforce the law as amended
column6: but his office would still pursue claims that DraftKings and FanDuel had engaged in false advertising and consumer fraud.FanDuel and DraftKings are in early-stage talks to merge
column7: people familiar with the matter told Reuters on Monday. (Additional reporting by Frank McGurty; editing by David Clarke and Cynthia Osterman)"	['Clarke'

column1: 4	4	http://reuters.com/article/us-exxon-mobil-climatechange-idUSKCN0Z400F	House panel claims oversight of state climate probes into Exxon	"
By Terry Wade and Ernest Scheyder
| HOUSTON
HOUSTON A Republican-led congressional committee sought on Friday to assert oversight over inquiries that about 20 states are making into Exxon Mobil and climate change
column2: reiterating demands to know more about state attorneys general's consultations with environmental groups.In a letter
column3: some 17 members of Congress and ranking members of the House Science
column4: Space
column5: and Technology Committee said they have broad jurisdiction that allows them to review investigations carried out by states. The committee was pushing back against state officials who have said they are not subject to federal oversight.The standoff is the latest in a high-stakes battle between the world's largest publicly traded oil company and a coalition of state attorneys general who have said they would go after Exxon in a bid to force congressional action to tackle climate change.About 20 state officials jointly said in March they would participate in inquiries into whether Exxon executives misled the public by contradicting research from company scientists that spelled out the threats of climate change.

column1: Prior to that March announcement
column2: some state officials met with a range of prominent environmental and investment groups that oppose fossil fuels.The House committee has complained the inquiries risk stifling free speech and scientific inquiry
column3: and that state officials were coordinating with special interest groups.The House committee demanded for the second time since May that state officials hand over all records of communications between their offices and outside groups.

column1: Congress has a responsibility to investigate whether such investigations are having a chilling effect on the free flow of scientific inquiry and debate regarding climate change
column2: the letter said.""People should be troubled by any attempt by members of Congress to silence or undercut basic investigatory authority by a state attorney general's office
column3: said Cyndi Roy Gonzalez
column4: a spokeswoman for Massachusetts Attorney General Maura Healey. ""Our office will not be intimidated by oil industry-backed members of the U.S. House of Representatives.""

column1: Exxon
column2: for its part
column3: has said it has acknowledged the reality of climate change for years and communicated this to investors.  On Wednesday
column4: Exxon asked a federal court to throw out a subpoena that would force it to hand over decades of documents on climate change to Healey's office. (Reporting By Terry Wade and Ernest Scheyder; Editing by Cynthia Osterman)"	[]	[]

column1: 6	6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-obama-parks-idUSKCN0Z310K	Obama family explores 'Big Room' cavern on national parks tour	"
By Roberta Rampton
| CARLSBAD CAVERNS NATIONAL PARK
column2: N.M.

column1: CARLSBAD CAVERNS NATIONAL PARK
column2: N.M. U.S. President Barack Obama and his family escaped the blistering heat of the Chihuahuan Desert on Friday when they went through a maze of ancient caverns where the only sound was the drip-dripping from stalactites.The subterranean adventure was the first stop on a working vacation during which Obama will spend some time with his teenaged daughters while making the case for more spending on conservation and curbing climate change.It was just like any other family holiday
column3: except the entourage of Secret Service agents
column4: aides and press who follow Obama wherever he goes had to descend the 754 feet (230 m) on elevators in eight shifts.""How cool is this?"" he said to the press in the dark
column5: damp alien landscape of the ""Big Room
column6: the best known of the labyrinth of limestone caves that actor Will Rogers once called the ""Grand Canyon with a roof on it."" The president is helping celebrate the centennial of the National Park Service while highlighting his plan to reduce climate-changing carbon emissions
column7: which he sees as part of the legacy of his time in office.The White House has said the changing climate evidenced by  droughts
column8: increased flooding and wildfires and stronger storms has put national parks at risk.

column1: The Obamas were due to fly west later on Friday to the Sierra Nevada mountains and Yosemite

column5: and the government is grappling with a $11.5 billion backlog of maintenance projects.

column1: At Carlsbad

column4: which will end on Jan. 20

column8: monuments and restrictions for development
column9: more than any other president.Interior Secretary Sally Jewell said national park visits in 2016 were on pace to beat last year's record of 307 million. Tourists contributed an estimated $300 billion to the economy

column2: senators formulate gun control compromise	"

column1: By Richard Cowan and Julia Edwards
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Some Republican senators tried on Friday to craft a compromise bill to impose limited gun restrictions in the face of pressure from Democrats and public rage over the Orlando mass shooting
column2: the deadliest in modern U.S. history.A gunman killed 49 people at the Orlando
column3: Florida
column4: gay nightclub last Sunday
column5: sparking a scramble over competing gun measures in the U.S. Senate.While past gun-control measures have failed to clear Congress
column6: the massacre
column7: coupled with public pressure and a suggestion by Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump that he can work with gun rights lobbyists to bring about change
column8: may be changing the picture.Republicans over the years have blocked gun control measures saying they step on Americans' right to bear arms as guaranteed under the U.S. Constitution. During a week-long Senate debate
column9: Democrats generally have criticized proposed Republican measures as being ineffective.Republicans and Democrats have offered four separate proposals to expand background checks on gun buyers and curb gun sales for people on terrorism ""watch lists."" But they seem destined to fail because of partisan politics and a requirement that any proposal muster 60 of the 100 votes in the U.S. Senate.MAINE SENATOR LEADING EFFORT

column1: Republican Susan Collins of Maine
column2: leading the new effort
column3: is considering a more tailored approach. It would prevent the sale of guns to terrorism suspects whose names appear on either the government's ""no-fly"" list
column4: which bans them from boarding planes
column5: or a so-called ""selectee"" list that requires additional screening at airports
column6: her office said in an emailed statement.These lists are much shorter than a broad terrorism watch list kept by the FBI.

column1: Collins' measure also includes a five-year ""look-back"" provision that would notify the government if someone who had been on the ""no-fly"" or ""selectee"" list in the last five years
column2: but was dropped
column3: purchases a gun. ""That would allow the FBI to put the individual under surveillance or take other appropriate action it deems necessary
column4: Collins' office said.The gun control issue is deeply divisive and there have been no major restrictions passed since 1994
column5: when Congress imposed a ban on semi-automatic assault weapons. That expired after 10 years.About 71 percent of Americans
column6: including eight out of 10 Democrats and nearly six out of 10 Republicans
column7: favor at least moderate regulations and restrictions on guns
column8: according to a Reuters/Ipsos poll conducted from Monday to Thursday. That was up from 60 percent in late 2013 and late 2014.    Vice President Joe Biden weighed in on the debate
column9: urging a public groundswell in support of banning the type of weapons that have been used in mass shootings. ""Assault weapons and high-capacity magazines should be banned from civilian ownership
column10: Biden said on Friday.Both the gunman in the Orlando attack
column12: and the married couple who carried out a December mass shooting that killed 14 people in San Bernardino
column14: were thought to have been inspired by militant Islamist groups abroad.

column1: PROPOSALS NEXT WEEK
Collins' proposal likely would be offered in the Republican-led Senate sometime next week
column2: provided the four other gun-control proposals fail to pass on Monday. Collins is working on the legislation with Senator Jeff Flake of Arizona and Kelly Ayotte of New Hampshire; she has also been talking to Democrats.A senior Democratic aide said that Democrats have concerns that under Collins' bill
column3: some people credibly suspected of involvement in terrorism would not be covered by the weapons ban.

column1: Collins told reporters on Thursday that barring everyone on terrorism watch lists from weapons purchases carried with it the risk of affecting people who have been swept onto the lists without good cause.U.S. authorities maintain several watch lists - the Federal Bureau of Investigation maintains three and the Office of the Director of National Intelligence runs one database. People are placed on such lists based on the threat level they are believed to pose.""What we're trying to do is not deny constitutional rights to a large group of individuals"" who find themselves on watch lists despite the fact that there might not be credible evidence of potential criminal intentions

column7: along with fellow Democrats
column8: set the U.S. Capitol abuzz by talking on the Senate floor for nearly 15 straight hours this week to demand that Congress act on gun control.Murphy said it was too early to say whether any Democrats would get on board with her approach.On Friday

column13: said it would push for curtailing access to assault-style rifles
column14: expanding background checks for firearms buyers and limiting the ability of suspected terrorists to purchase guns. (Additional reporting by Susan Cornwell and Doina Chaicu; Editing by Frances Kerry and Howard Goller)"	['Ayotte'

column1: 9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-beverages-sodatax-bloomberg-idUSKCN0Z3275	Bloomberg looks West after bankrolling Philadelphia soda tax win	"
By Luc Cohen
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK After successfully funding a campaign to pass a soda tax in Philadelphia
column2: billionaire Michael Bloomberg is preparing to fund similar efforts in several other cities
column3: giving new momentum to  measures seeking to limit soft drink consumption.The former New York City mayor contributed the bulk of the money for the pro-soda tax side in Philadelphia

column5: California this year

column7: a senior adviser to Bloomberg

column11: Wolfson said. The billionaire's planned backing raises the stakes for the powerful beverage industry
column12: which has lobbied hard to defeat many of the 43 municipal and state-level attempts to implement a soda tax that have failed since 2008. Before this week
column14: California was the only U.S. city with a soda tax. But the success in Philadelphia
column15: the country's fifth-largest city with a diverse population of 1.6 million
column16: could mark a turning point as Americans become more aware of health campaigners' message that sugary soft drinks contribute to obesity and diabetes.

column1: If Berkeley was a tremor

column3: and we expect there will be more earthquakes going forward
column4: Wolfson said. As New York's mayor

column6: prevent residents from buying sodas with food stamps

column8: and all three measures were ultimately defeated.Philadelphia's Mayor Jim Kenney took a different approach
column9: emphasizing the revenue benefits of the tax over the health angle. The city council approved the measure in a 13-4 vote on Thursday after activists raised a total of around $2 million

column1: Feeley and Wolfson both said the soda industry outspent the pro-tax campaign. A spokeswoman for the American Beverage Association (ABA)
column2: which represents Coca-Cola Co and PepsiCo and funded a local group opposing the tax
column3: said the group did not yet have a final tally for how much it spent.The spokeswoman added that the group would ""oppose all discriminatory tax proposals."" The group has said the tax's passage in Philadelphia was the result of unique local political conditions and unlikely to have a ripple effect in other cities.

column1: The ABA said on Thursday it would sue Philadelphia to stop the tax
column2: and Wolfson did not rule out the possibility that Bloomberg would contribute to aid the city's defense. Wolfson declined to specify an amount that Bloomberg was willing to spend on the San Francisco and Oakland efforts
column3: but noted that he was ""not in a position to match soda dollar for dollar."" Bloomberg's contributions are meant to help ""level the playing field
column4: he said.(Story corrects first name of Howard Wolfson in paragraph two previously said Michael.) (Additional reporting by Chris Prentice; Editing by Tom Brown)"	['Cohen']	[]
